identificationModule.briefTitle: Sedation vs. Intubation for Endovascular Stroke TreAtment
identificationModule.officialTitle: Sedation vs. Intubation for Endovascular Stroke TreAtment

responsibleParty.investigatorTitle: Leading sub-investigator, Principal Investigator: PD Dr. Julian Bösel, MD

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Sedation vs Intubation for Endovascular Stroke TreAtment Trial (SIESTA) is a prospective, randomised controlled, monocentric, two-armed, comparative trial. Patients are randomized 1 : 1 to either non-intubated state or to intubated state for endovascular stroke treatment. Otherwise, no principal differences in intensive care treatment are intended, and standard operating procedures are applied to ensure uniform management decisions in fields such as ventilation, sedation, cardio-vascular and cerebral monitoring and management.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Early recanalization is an important, if not the most important, factor concerning reconstitution of patients´ health in ischaemic stroke. This is the reason why patients with extended stroke are increasingly subjected to an endovascular stroke therapy (EST).

Matter of ongoing debate is how to sedate these patients during intervention. Some clinicians prefer an intubation due to a reduction of patients´movements and therefore potentially lowering complication rates (injury by catheter, aspiration e.g.).

On the other hand retrospective investigations hypothesize that general anaesthesia is associated with peri-interventional hypotension followed by poorer clinical outcome.

The best anaesthaesiologic management in endovascular stroke therapy to this point of time is not known. The investigators therefore designed this study comparing intubated state with general anaesthesia vs. non-intubated state with conscious sedation during EST, focusing on patients´ outcome.

armGroups.label: Intubation
armGroups.description: Intubation and invasive mechanical ventilation + endovascular recanalisation

armGroups.label: No Intubation
armGroups.description: Conscious sedation and non-invasive ventilatory support + endovascular recanalisation

interventions.name: Endovascular recanalisation
interventions.description: Endovascular recanalisation by mechanical thrombectomy with e.g. stent retriever device, possibly following intravenous thrombolysis within a "bridging concept"

primaryOutcomes.measure: National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) after 24 hours
primaryOutcomes.description: Neurological improvement of NIHSS 24 hours after intervention

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Outcome after 3 month using the modified Rankin Scale (mRS)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Assessing the neurological outcome after 3 months with the mRS.

secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Mortality-rate until timepoint of discharge, an expected average of 3 weeks.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Mortality-rate within the first 3 months after intervention.

otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed until timepoint of discharge, an expected average of 3 weeks.
Evaluation of Adverse Events as a Measure of Safety and Tolerability until timepoint of discharge, an expected average of 3 weeks.

otherOutcomes.description: Recanalisation status is classified according to the Thrombolysis in Cerebral Infarction classification (TICI).
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Duration of intervention with an expected average of 2 hours

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* age ≥18 years
* acute stroke in anterior circulation
* occlusion of carotid artery and/ or middle cerebral artery
* planned mechanical recanalisation
* informed consent from patient or legal representative

Exclusion Criteria:

* age \< 18 years
* informed consent not obtainable
* coma
* agitation
* vomiting
* difficult airway management
* additional cerebral hemorrhage
